Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2011 11:03PM CorinneM1 wrote: Hi there. You will learn all of the lingo really quickly.  I was diagnosed at the end of May and just had my surgery on June 23rd.  I had a double mastectomy (BMX) with immediate reconstruction and had tissue expanders put in (TE).
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 06:46AM - edited Jan 8, 2012 06:51AM by CorinneM1 I got my news over the phone as well.  I was ready though with a list of questions in case the news was cancer.  I think it was better to prepare for the worst news, hope for the best. I asked what grade I was. What type it was, if it was hormone postive, HER negative or positive and what my next steps were.  Granted, I knew nothing about grade, hormones or HER, but I read that you should ask these questions and I did. Once I got the information I spent few days researching what I could before I met with my breast surgeon who was able to give me more details. Have these questions at the ready in case the news isn't what you hoped for. And oh yeah, this is one of the worst parts. The waiting.  Even if the news isn't good, you can start to put together a plan on what's next.  This is what messed with my head the most. The not knowing and not knowing what to do next.  Once all of the pieces came together--it was something like this Okay I have cancer...what next...BMX...what next...decide on course of follow up treatment...what next...begin treatment...what next...live your life and overcome.
Posts.Title: How did you hear biopsy results--phone or appt? frazzledmom schoolmom

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 06:28PM CorinneM1 wrote: I was waiting to post here until I was sure.  My name is Corinne, and I recently was diagnosed with ILC.  I am 39 years old and live in Chicago.  I had a BMX 3 weeks ago, although the ILC was only found in 1 breast (left).  I was told that I am grade 1/stage 1, with the largest tumor being 1.5cm (I had 3). I am recovering well, minimal pain just the tightness and akward feeling of TE.  I am awaiting to find out what my follow up treatment will be as the Onctotype was sent out and I don't have the reports yet.  I may have to do radiation due to a close margin, which will also be determined early next week. Nice to meet you all.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 01:31PM CorinneM1 wrote: Zumbagirl...get a copy of all of your records.  MRI, biopsy, surgery reports everything.  I asked for copies of everything and I have them in a file.  Its overwhemling and as I explained to my sister for the first few visits to various doctors, I felt as if they were talking to me and I was under water.  I could hear them, nodded along like I understood and walked out not understanding.  Having the copies send to me allowed me to go back and read more about my stage/area etc. This will help you as well should you ever want to work with a different MO, RO etc etc.  You have everthing at the ready.  Oh, can you can also have a CD copy of your MRI.  You should have this as well.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 05:20PM CorinneM1 wrote: Holly, I had a very different diagnosis, but I had a mastectomy and I am currently on Tamoxifen for the next 5+ years (they are stating somekind of hormone therapy for 10 years). I am 40. Everyone's recovery is different.  I was back to work within 2 weeks, and was fine physically and mentally.  I haven't had any issues or horror stories with Tamoxifen either. Is this what your breast surgeron is stating--either/or mastectomy or tamoxifen as a preventative? You are young. Do you have kids or do you plan on having any children?  Pregnancy and tamoxifen is a no-no.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Vs Mastectomy winter2011 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: CorinneM1 wrote: I am considering chemo, and strangely I am okay with losing the hair.  I was in the mood for a new style anyway.  What I don't dig about chemo is losing the eyebrows and the eyelashes.  I suppose I will learn how to draw in an eyebrow, while looking for a good wig with bangs BUT I have crazy long dark lashes.  I have read here that they fall out after treatment and grow back pretty fast and I would use latisse to help speed this up/fill in when they are sparse. However, has anyone used latisse during chemo?  The entire time?  If so, what were the results.  I am considering doing 4 rounds of T/C for my grade 1 stage 1 ILC.  CorinneM1 ILC Grade 1 Stage 1 ER/PR+ HER neg. BMX, no chemo, no rads, tamoxifen for 5+ years Log in to post a reply
